p: The results of surface relaxation showed that the surface structure with the double-cyclodextrin was the most stable one which was at least 1.5 × 10 −4 kcal/mol lower than other surfaces. Based on this surface structure, the models of the glucose rings in SCU inside and outside the CD-MOF surface were constructed and simulated respectively ( Fig. 5B and C). The results showed that the structure of the glucose ring inside the CD-MOF surface ( Fig. 5B) was more stable (129 kcal/mol lower than the other case), which was also the maximum possibility in the realistic circumstances. The energy of the more stable surface was 34 kcal/mol lower than the blank surface, which lead to a lower possibility of agglomeration or great flowability between particles. In these two primary typical statuses, the difference of surface free energy of SCU@CD-MOF meant that the three-dimensional orientation of SCU inside CD-MOF would affect the surface properties of the powders, which possibly contributed to its laryngeal deposition.
